citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility has not developed, documented, or followed a species-specific plan directed by the attending veterinarian for
the environmental enhancement of young non-human primates (NHPs) or individually-housed NHPs that are unable to
see and hear other non-human primates. A 14-week old ring-tailed lemur is being housed separately from the other
lemurs to provide specialized attention and to protect him from injury from the other lemurs. He cannot see or hear other
lemurs in his current housing.
Lemurs have complex social, environmental, and medical needs. Infants and young juveniles require special attention and
care in order to ensure proper socialization and to decrease stress. Additionally, lemurs are a social species and require
special consideration when housed without being able to see and hear non-human primates of their own or compatible
species. The written environmental enhancement plan (EEP) does not have information for these special considerations,
nor was one implemented for this NHP. Without these specialized attention and environmental enhancements, NHPs may
develop abnormal behaviors and could experience psychological distress.
The facility must develop, document, and implement an adequate enrichment plan per the attending veterinarian’s
instructions for their NHPs that includes special attention regarding enhancement of the environment for young and
juvenile NHPs and those individually housed unable to see and hear NHPs of their own or compatible species.
Correct by October 20, 2025

Two enclosures were not maintained in good repair and sharp metal points were observed.
*The wooden shed that provides shelter for two Patagonian cavies has metal chicken wire attached to the interior walls to
prevent the cavies from chewing on the wood. The wire has detached in at least two places, leaving sharp points.
*One side of the metal wrapping covering the door frame of a pig shelter has come loose at the bottom. This shelter
houses one pig.
Sharp points may injure animals. Outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good
repair to protect the animals from injury.
Correct by September 25, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.81(c) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility has not developed, documented, or followed a species-specific plan directed by the attending veterinarian for 
the environmental enhancement of young non-human primates (NHPs) or individually-housed NHPs that are unable to 
see and hear other non-human primates. A 14-week old ring-tailed lemur is being housed separately from the other 
lemurs to provide specialized attention and to protect him from injury from the other lemurs. He cannot see or hear other 
lemurs in his current housing.  
 
Lemurs have complex social, environmental, and medical needs. Infants and young juveniles require special attention and 
care in order to ensure proper socialization and to decrease stress. Additionally, lemurs are a social species and require 
special consideration when housed without being able to see and hear non-human primates of their own or compatible 
species. The written environmental enhancement plan (EEP) does not have information for these special considerations, 
nor was one implemented for this NHP. Without these specialized attention and environmental enhancements, NHPs may 
develop abnormal behaviors and could experience psychological distress. 
 
The facility must develop, document, and implement an adequate enrichment plan per the attending veterinarian’s 
instructions for their NHPs that includes special attention regarding enhancement of the environment for young and 
juvenile NHPs and those individually housed unable to see and hear NHPs of their own or compatible species. 
 
Correct by October 20, 2025 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
Two enclosures were not maintained in good repair and sharp metal points were observed.  
 
*The wooden shed that provides shelter for two Patagonian cavies has metal chicken wire attached to the interior walls to 
prevent the cavies from chewing on the wood. The wire has detached in at least two places, leaving sharp points.  
*One side of the metal wrapping covering the door frame of a pig shelter has come loose at the bottom. This shelter 
houses one pig.

Sharp points may injure animals. Outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good 
repair to protect the animals from injury. 
 
Correct by September 25, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
